factoid: The creature is a creature that wriggles anywhere.
The creature has been degraded.
The creature now wants to bob up again.
The creature has been proposing some scheme or other.
The creature has crawled into the enemy’s picket line at night.
The creature is a brave fellow.
Pierre took off his hat and bowed respectfully to Kutúzov.
Dólokhov concluded that if he reported to the Serene Highness, he might be sent away or told that the Serene Highness knew what he was reporting.
Dólokhov concluded that if he reported to the Serene Highness, he should not lose anything.
Dólokhov believes that if he is right, he should render a service to his Fatherland for which he is ready to die.
Dólokhov offers himself as a man who will not spare his skin if the Serene Highness requires such a man.
Dólokhov may prove useful to the Serene Highness.
Kutúzov’s laughing eye narrowed more and more as he looked at Pierre.
Borís told Pierre that the militia have put on clean white shirts to be ready to die.
Borís said "What heroism, Count!" to Pierre.
Borís said this to Pierre in order to be overheard by the Serene Highness.
Borís knew that Kutúzov would be attracted by those words.
Kutúzov asked Pierre: What are you saying about the militia?
Pierre said that the militia have put on clean shirts in preparation for tomorrow, for death.
Kutúzov said: "Ah... a wonderful, a matchless people!"
Kutúzov closed his eyes and swayed his head.
Kutúzov repeated: "A matchless people!" with a sigh.
Kutúzov asked Pierre: So you want to smell gunpowder?
Kutúzov said: Yes, it’s a pleasant smell.
Kutúzov said: I have the honor to be one of your wife’s adorers.
Kutúzov asked: Is she well?
Kutúzov said: My quarters are at your service.
Kutúzov began looking about absent‑mindfully as if forgetting all he wanted to say or do.
Kutúzov beckoned Andrew Kaysárov, his adjutant’s brother.
Kutúzov asked Andrew Kaysárov: Those verses of Márin’s, how do they go?
Kutúzov mentioned that Márin wrote verses about Gerákov: "Lectures for the corps inditing".
Kutúzov said: Recite them, recite them.
Kaysárov recited the verses.
Kutúzov nodded his head to the rhythm of the verses.
When Pierre left Kutúzov, Dólokhov approached Pierre and took his hand.
Dólokhov said: I am very glad to meet you here, Count.
Dólokhov said: On the eve of a day when God alone knows who of us is fated to survive, I am glad of this opportunity to tell you that I regret the misunderstandings that occurred between us.
Dólokhov said: I should wish you not to have any ill feeling for me.
Dólokhov begged Pierre to forgive him.
Pierre looked at Dólokhov with a smile, not knowing what to say.
Dólokhov embraced Pierre with tears in his eyes.
Dólokhov kissed Pierre.
Borís said a few words to his general.
Count Bennigsen turned to Pierre and proposed that Pierre should ride with him along the line.
Count Bennigsen said: It will interest you.
Pierre replied: Yes, very much.
Kutúzov left for Tatárinova.
Bennigsen and his suite, with Pierre among them, set out on a ride along the line.
Bennigsen descended the highroad from Górki to the bridge.
The officer pointed out the bridge as being the center of their position.
Rows of fragrant new‑mown hay lay by the riverside at the bridge.
Bennigsen rode across the bridge into the village of Borodinó.
Bennigsen turned left, passing many troops and guns, and came to a high knoll where militiamen were digging.
The high knoll was a redoubt, as yet unnamed.
The redoubt later became known as the Raévski Redoubt or the Knoll Battery.
Pierre paid no special attention to the redoubt.
Pierre did not know that the redoubt would become more memorable to him than any other spot on the plain of Borodinó.
